description.text:
Made this as my ABS was suffering from moisture absorption causing poor prints.
The tub was £3 from Asda and just the perfect size, the axle was just a piece of wooden clothes rail from an old wardrobe (or you could use PVC pipe) and the axle supports were printed in ABS at 0.3mm then screwed to the inside of the tub (diameter of the axle rod is 22mm, inside diameter of supports is 22.5mm and the screw holes are 4mm).
I have a bag of silica gel in the tub to help reduce moisture. Update : Stoppers - these are a tighter fit than the supports but can still be moved along the axle to fit different spool sizes. They stop smaller spools from moving about while printing . Printed at 0.3mm. Filament feeder - 2mm diameter nozzle for 1.75mm filament. Mine is pushed through a hole in the lid and glued to the inside or you could just glue it to the top. Printed at 0.2mm.
I used 123D Design for the 3d modelling.

comments.text:

https://www.walmart.com/ip/Sterilite-Large-EZ-Carry-ShowOffs-Clear-Spicy-Lime/48194361
Later i will add a gasket to seal it up better.
Also for the filament plug i changed it out for a push in bowden fitting. will add my pics to the made tab.

description.text: Our team need about 100 knobs to complete a project. Trying to buy the knobs locally was costly and limited stock. We decided to draw it up and print them. This was my first attempt at creating threads. The knob is 50mm with 5 arcs for finger grips. The knob accepts 1/4"-20 x.472 insert nuts.

Printed on the Replicator using MakerWare. ABS, 100% infill, 2 shells, .27 layer height, 230 extruder, 110 platform.
Once complete simply screw the insert nut into the knob. There is an upper end stop that you can really twist the nut into, to make it stay. If needed you can use an epoxy to make sure it does not back out.

author: PiPPi

title: UP! extruder modification 4, Recreus Hot end

description.text: I decided it was time to get rid of the all steel barrel in my hot end so it would be more reliable with PLA and I wanted to try the new flexible rubber like materials and the new Recreus hot end looked to be a relatively easy mod to make to my "UP Plus Pro"

The mount bar, 13DP1001-00 should be machined in aluminum.
The Plastic parts should be printed with as close to solid as you can.
The Recreus hot end can be purchased here:
http://recreus.com/hotends/23upgrade-175mm-hot-end-.html#
You will need to bore to a larger diameter the hole for the existing UP temp sensor.
I had to cut 1 fin from the heat sink to fit the space available but it does not seem to effect function in any way.
This mod uses my previous parts:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16711
I forgot to include the file "11-DP1002-00" the extruder backbone, it will space the plastic off the face of the extruder motor 0.600mm and help insulate the incoming plastic from the heat of the stepper motor, this means you may have to pull the sharp toothed gear a few mm's away from the face of the motor to keep the filament centered in the teeth.

comments.text:
Recent update,
I noticed some leakage around the hot block to nozzle and hotblock to barrel so I dismantled the extruder and found that the new barrel was broken.
I open palmed my forehead and realized the barrel was a M6 screw with a diameter 4mm bore, this meant a 1mm wall thickness but this meant after tapping the threads, at the root of the the threads there would only be about 0.500mm of wall thickness on a part that needs a lot of torsion to install and lock up.
In short the barrel unzipped into a slinky.
I've sent a request to Recreus for a replacement so now we shall see how responsive they are.
comments.author: DrewPetitclerc

comments.text:
Update,
The people at Recreus have wonderful fast customer service, they responded next day (Sunday) and shipped a new barrel the following Monday, it arrived 2 days later on Wednesday. Fantastic service!
The new barrel is also a new design, they increased the material thickness of the SST barrel and reduces the wall thickness of the PTFE tube, they also added a machined step with a nice chamfer for filament entry, the only question I have is the reason for a relief cut in the thread about 10mm from one end, maybe they have a reason but I can not figure it out.
Anyway, got it all installed and printer is very happy, now to try a few new materials.

title: Case for Intel Edison Arduino Expander Board

description.text:
This is a case for the Intel Edison with the Arduino Expander Board. The slots allow access to Arduino shields. All edge I/O are accessible.
I've included guides for control of the 5 on-board switches using separately printed switch extenders (I'll add the STL once I get the geometries optimized). Also included are holes intended for light-pipes for on-board LED's using a material like T-Glase or some other transparent/translucent material (STL in progress).
Update: I've uploaded the switch extensions. These allow you to operate all 5 board switches.
Print the case.  Remove the tabs.  Insert Edison and Arduino Expansion board.  Secure with 4 screws inserted through the bottom of the case.

title: Prusa I3 Rework BODY-EXTRUDEUR-WADE-1.75mm-with-support with Solidworks 2014 Source
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I could not find any source files to work with for my I3 Rework so I am slowly making SW source files for them. All of them are painstakingly done by hand so may not be an identical copy. and/or may be missing something I overlooked, but are as close as I will get to the originals. This is the 1.75mm filament version but in the source you will see (in the source tree) "Cut-Extrude-Filament Hole" That is the hole you can make to any size you wish.
If you find anything wrong let me know so I can fix it as this is a WIP.

Make sure your slicer has its "detect thin walls" option/type of option toggled on before you slice this.
.
Dead center of the filament hole to the edge where the large gear goes is 14mm then add washers, and the big gear's depth, to that to find out what distance you exactly need for your hobbed bolt.

comments.text: what spec's on the hobbed bolt for this one?  IE: distance from bolt head to hobbed teeth.

comments.text: Dead center of the hole to the edge is 14mm then add washers and the gear itself to that to find out what you exactly need.

Would have to change the gear to have a 5mm bolt head instead of the 8mm one.  I think the m7 gear is 8mm outside diameter.  If the grub screw is flush or below the surface locked down it should fit.

comments.text: Well, that version of Slic3r is ancient, and I do mean very ancient on the order of 18-24 months.  Everything you see in these models is exactly, or so close you can call them exactly, the dimensions of the original models.  Yes, I printed out the original (why I made this) and this version.  The support uses 0.5mm thick walls which slicer has no issues replicating unless you are using slicer wall widths greater than 0.5mm.
comments.author: charlie68

comments.text: Hi again. You encouraged me to "upgrade" from Pronterface with slicer 0.7.1; so i started using Repetier host with Slicer 1.0.0RC2 (yeah still old, but I had it installed). I still had the same problem, so I went hunting /checking / testing slicer settings and just tried checking "Print Settings->Layers and perimeters ->Quality->Detect thin walls" ... and that did it. It now slices with all support structures showing beautifully in the gcode view.
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text: You are most welcome and I forgot about that setting because I have had it always on since day one because slic3r refused to slice the thin wall calibration cube, lol, so I had to set it and as Ron Popeil used to say I really did "Set it and forget it". :)

description.text:
Dual extrusion for the Simple? Is it really possible? Honestly, I don't know but would like to find out.
Yes, I got a little crazy. Printed the prototype, but ran out of time and never installed or tested. Thought I would just throw it out there for anybody else who was feeling a bit crazy and may want to give it a go.
No warranty, no guarantee, you are on your own because I don't have the first clue about how to actually print with dual extruders.
If you try it, let me know I would love to hear your feedback.
Will work with any of my 300mm no sag mods. Single or double precision compatible.
2014-11-18: Uploaded a bowden conversion part so either side (or both) can be converted to a bowden by using a 1/8 NPT push tube fiting.
2014-12-04: Uploaded a bowden conversion with the motor mounting removed.

title: Electric Toothbrush Head Holder for Cup

description.text:
This is a holder/stand for toothbrush heads from the Braun Oral-B(r) toothbrush.  
The head holders that often comes with the toothbrush, gets very dirty, and it is some work to keep it clean.   
This head holder/stand goes inside a cup or glass and is a lot easier to clean, and the brush heads dry faster. There are cuts in the bottom to allow water to drip out (and into the bottom of the cup, where it will evaporate from a potentially much larger surface). There is a slot so you can see the color rings used to tell heads apart, and there is a holder that will grab the side of the cup.   
It is designed to work in a cup with diameter approx 100 mm, but it works well in classes down to 70-80 mm too. (Thats about 3-4" I think).  
Created in Freecad.

The models (dual and single) are somewhat tricky to print nice. They do not have a lot of contact with the bed, and there are a lot of non-straight lines in them. You will probably want to use a brim, and perhaps 0.2 mm layer height. Less, if you can make it.  
I am quite interessted in feedback from people that tries to print this model, as I might try to redesign it to be easier to print.

-small (almost same as original, except 3x perimeter wall width)
-compact (most compact possible, bit higher, uses least plastic, smallest hub)
-sturdy (designed for 7mm cables. bit more space, bit more sturdy , thicker walls, smaller openings) 4m has just "cheap" and "deluxe" versions. deluxe uses more plastic, is bit more sturdy and has larger hub, also deluxe accepts 6mm cables. 8m is mainly for very elastic 5mm wires, like microphone or guitar cables 20m is a large spool for stuff like garden power cord. 6mm max.
beware of how it snaps before you attempt to print, also be carefull - wire should be quite elastic, otherwise it'll jam. have fun. 8m

This is a simpler version of an existing 40mm fan mount found here. When we first got our printer running, there were no fans blowing directly at the extruder and the original design had a hard time printing cleanly. This is a simpler version which should print just fine without fans or supports. I updated the original design with Blender, so the .blend file is attached. It attaches to the fan mounts on the X-Carriage (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18657). We ended up with a 10mm thick fan and a standard 20mm thick fan on either side of the extruder.
Should print pretty well on a system with no fans mounted - we printed it with 20% in-fill, 2 loops, and no supports.  YMMV.
Should be ready to print, but I haven't tested it yet.

description.text:
Simple geometries mixing curves with with right angles. Print one of each size with the same color, or make one red, one white and one green (great with semi-transparent filament), and you have a nice Christmas arrangement with flameless tealights.
I uploaded three individual files for each one of the three sizes (small, medium, and large), but you can just resize either file as you want.

Design made in Tinkercad, nothing too complicated, just combining different geometries. The only thing to care about is to have the right dimension for the part where the tealight would sit.
Printed in about 3 1/2 hr with no problems. No supports needed. Resolution was 0.20 mm.

title: Sanguinololu Case with mounting lugs for 1.3a

description.text:
I liked the original thing, but thought it would be better to use the base only and add a couple of mounting lugs to secure the case directly to the 2020 rail on the rear of the printer.
I also reduced the height of the side walls, as it will be left open.
Lets you adjust the stepper pots if you need and keeps the PCB open to allow for better airflow.
We did add a 60mm fan on a clip above the base.  We tried adding the fan mount to the base, but had problems with the fan mount parts not being strong enough.
We'll revisit that at a later date.
Worked will with 2 loops, and 35% in-fill.

Blender, dawg.

The Minister's Cat is a word game we play with our kids on long car trips, or at least it is when we can pry them away from their bickering and iPods for a few minutes. Players take turns describing the Minister's Cat with an adjective, progressing through the alphabet as they go. First player gets "A," and says the Minister's Cat is an awesome cat. Second player uses "B" and says the Minister's Cat is a brave cat. And so on. If you can't think of a word, you're out. Today, the Minister's Cat is a Voronoi cat. The zip file contains the spiffy Voronoi cat, and a generic cat and base for you to remix so we can all play The Minister's Cat on Thingiverse.

No assembly necessary.  
There's some known hinky geometry in the Voronoi cat base, but that didn't stop RepG 37 from slicing this for me. The generic cat and base should be trouble-free.  
This model is part of my continuing effort to meow "Voronoi" the word of the year for 2013.

A spool handle to be used on top of 3D printer frame. Originally designed for Monkeyfab Prime3D, but the handle should also fit similar 6 mm thick frames. http://3dwpraktyce.pl/2014/09/nowy-uchwyt-na-filament/

All parts except the handle can be printed using PLA with standard settings and no supports.
The handle itself needs some support material. I recommend printing it in natural position to get the top surface of the axis well finished.
The tube element can be skipped - it depends how tight plugs fits your spool. Actually, you can skip the plugs also - then just hang your spool directly on main part axis :)

The Los Angeles Lakers are one of the greatest teams to exist in the National Basketball Association (NBA). They have won a total of 16 championships and serve as a home to many NBA greats such as Magic Johnson, Wilt Chamberlain, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Kobe Bryant and many more.
This model is meant for a dual extruder but can still look good if printed on a single. The inside part height from the base plate should be lowered a tiny bit if printing all in the same color so the contours of the model can still be seen. There is also a keychain edition!

DUAL:
Download the .thing file. Render the model. No supports are needed for the stand alone. They may be needed for the keychain. A raft will prevent the possibility of the initial layers peeling up off the plate.
Single:
Download the .thing file. Move the center piece down the Z-axis a few mm. This will allow the features of the logo to still appear when printed in one color.

This is a simple holder for the Belkin 4-Port Ultra-Slim desktop Hub (Product Number F4U038). The holder can be screwed on somewhere and the Hub simply snaps in.
Update (2013-01-10): I updated the holder to be 2mm higher and thus having a bit more grip than before. I also enlarged the mounting holes a bit.
Print and snap in the hub. The OpenSCAD file is attached in case you want to modify it.

GT2 2mm pitch timing belt pulley that fits a 5mm stepper motor shaft.
Best printed with .35 nozzle and thin layers (I printed 0.1mm), print more than 1 copy for better cooling.

author: muhammad_elarbi

description.text:
Case for Sanguinololu board to fit a 80mm fan. The case has thin walls and bottom (1.5mm). Top is 2mm thick. It has windows for the power cables, the bed and extruder resistors, and the usb cable. All other cables (motors, thermistors, endstops) exit from a single opening on the right side, so this case is for Sanguinololus that have their molex connectors aligned vertically (see photos).
There might be another version with windows for all connections to fit those Sanguinololus that have molex connectors oriented horizontally.

Hey everyone this is my first design. My sister wanted a "real" mario 1 up to play with so, I made this.
Please consider donating some shibes at DF7tumDH98FUCbPRZVPBhug6cCCRCkF7ZF

This is a doorbell for the London Hackspace.
It has a large red button, speaker grill, bi-coloured LED, and the hackspace H logo engraved on the side. It is controlled by an arduino, and when pressed it makes a noise, flashes the space's lights, puts a message on the LED notification board, and also sends a message to the #london-hack-space IRC channel.
This was made with the box-o-tron script, then tweeked and extra parts added in qcad.

comments.text: It is so cool to see other people using my scripting , BOX ON :)

author: mgold

title: Remington Model 700 Sling Stud Picatinny Bipod Mount

description.text:
So you just picked up a new Remington model 700 and are eager to race to the range to test its tack-driving precision when you realize the so called awesome H-S precision stock (it is awesome) on it doesn't have any good way to mount your picatinny bipod, so you won't even get to see the accuracy if you can't aim the rifle in a stable manner.  
Not wanting to wait for a new bipod or mount, I took some quick measurements and extruded some drawings of a NATO spec picatinny rail,  clicked print, and there, a bipod mount! .. or something like that (see pics).

Took it to the range and it broke almost as soon as I propped the bipod on the table :( so I used some wood for support that day, but I still needed a temporary solution while I wait for my new Harris bipod to come (shown in last pic -- it mounts to the studs directly).  
I removed the unused picatinny slots, resulting in one slot right in the middle, my hopes that this one would be stronger.  It lasted at least one range session, and my gun was only a .22-250 so the recoil forces exerted on the layers wasn't too bad, but now I have a real mount solution (See last pic!!).

This made a great temporary fix so I am posting it although I'm not expecting that many downloads because most people I know who shoot these guns are equipment snobs and will frown upon your cool 3D printed plastic mount because it isn't metal.  Metal is ideal, but I can't fabricate that quickly, cheaply and precisely all at once.  Hooray for 3D printing!
If you only need 1 Picatinny slot, print R700BPMnt2.0.stl because that's the only one I could get to actually hold up to anything.  If you need more than one slot, well you're SOL.

You can try the old ones, and I have included them in case anyone wants to fab one out of metal, but you're probably better off just buying something or getting a better bipod setup (see last pic).  1.0 was the first version but should only be used if you have abnormally long sling stud screws.  I'd fab this one in metal if I had to pick, and buy new studs if you're going through all that effort.  1.1 is like 1.0 but is for the stock sling studs.  This will probably be too weak to hold up to much.  Use 2.0 if at all possible, though it doesn't look as cool.

Print desired rail using 100% infill, unscrew your sling studs, and use them to mount this to your stock.  I have an H-S precision stock, but I believe the distance between the two studs has some kind of manufacturing standard behind it so it may work on other stocks.  Have fun punching paper!

description.text: Made to hold a cheapo framed household mirror. Designed for a 6D common nail. Larger than a normal mirror clip because it accommodates the mirror's frame.
Modeled in SketchUp. I just needed the frame depth, and width. along with the diameter of the nail and the nail head.

comments.text: This is excellent and just what I needed to print immediately. One note I'd add to this STL file is that it contains errors. Sketchup is notorious for creating erroneous models when exporting to STL. If you have Netfabb Basic, it will fix it for you, but for those that don't, consider uploading a fixed model. Again, this is just what I needed. Thanks!
comments.author: tonyjaco

comments.text: Hey, just wanted to offer a bit of improvement. Maybe see if you can round the corner a bit. It'll reduce the stress on the part. Not sure how heavy the frame is that it is holding?
comments.author: theOrange

comments.text: Please feel free to remix this. This one is very primitive and basic. Another improvement would be to to design for screws instead of nails; have a wider diameter hole and a deeper area for the screw head. Nails aren't great for this type of wall. But, nails are what I had on hand. This mirror and frame are luckily very light. Thank you for the recommendation. I like to learn how things can be improved in the future.
comments.author: theOrange

author: diabetemonster

description.text:
This is an extruder design that is optimized for 3D printing or milling on a cnc mill.  I've played with several of the existing extruder designs and found elements to dislike on all of them so far.  Typically, you need to dismantle the entire extruder to perform the most mundane maintainence, which is crazy.  I've played with the standard Mendel extruder, Wade's, and Makerbot Mk4.  I've heard good things about the Paxtruder, so this design borrows heavily from that design(plastic pusher instead of roller) although here it's a PTFE button that is 3/8" dia and .230" LG.  The material is available in 3/8" round and is soft enough to slice with an exacto blade.  We turned ours down from some 5/8" PTFE round that we had laying around for making thermal insulators.  It also uses the clever dual bolt-pattern of the Makerbot MK5 so that it can accept a gearhead DC motor or a stepper.
I don't have access to a lasercutter, so this extruder was designed to be milled or printed.  The radii in the inside corners are to allow clearance for a 1/4" endmill.  We printed a quickie today in anticipation of machining an aluminum one, and it works so well that we'll probably just keep using the printed one.
Ease of maintainence is key here.  The motor comes out readily by removing 4 screws (multiple motor failures have made this an important feature at the Heatsync Labs hackerspace).  The bore for the motor bearing is eliptical since the bearing only needs support opposite the pusher.  This means that the motor/pinion/bearing can all drop out as a unit without disassembly and the extruder can remain mounted on the machine.  This is an improvement over other designs that are a headache to maintain and usually require complete removal and/or disassembly of the extruder itself.  Also the extruder body is extremely small, so it can be printed quickly and it fits easily into the machine.  It's less than half the size of a Wade and probably only 70% of the size of a Mk4.

comments.text: I really like this design as well. Is there something that keeps the plunger from falling out or is its removability an intended feature?
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: Thanks.  The original plan was a milled aluminum extruder with a rectangular delrin plunger like on the paxstruder.  There was going to be a little flat plate that captured the delrin pusher and screwed onto the main housing.  What acutally happened was that we printed this incomplete version and one of the guys in the lab who was frustrusted with our Mk4 extruder said "Let's try it."  We started digging around to find some delrin to use for the pusher, couldn't find any, then spotted a bar of PTFE which is why we ended up with a round button.  The button gets trapped behind the edge of the bearing which keeps it from falling out if you remove the filament.  However, we've extruded some big parts without the bearing installed and the button still stays put.  The PTFE is soft enough that once it clamps the fiber a little channel forms in it which seems to keep it in place pretty well.  I'm thinking about building a little wall into the part to retain the pusher so that there would be the option of using the flat delrin pusher or the button.  I don't know how the button is going to hold-up long-term.  I was hoping that I'd start getting feedback from people that build it so that I know which direction to go next.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: I like the design but there is no support for the end of the motor shaft. Standard makerbot gearmotors will tear themselves up without a support of the outside of the shaft. I dont see that it would be a issue with a stepper motor since they are supported with bearings on both ends of the shaft though.
comments.author: rbisping

comments.text: A bearing goes on the end of the motor shaft and is supported by the large bearing pocket.  The bearing was not installed when the picture was taken because we were having trouble with a flaky motor and wanted to be able to see what was going on.  The next time I'm in the lab I'll take a picture with the bearing installed so that it's more clear.
comments.author: rbisping

description.text:
I  remixed another instance of bender I found a month or so ago, but forgot how to model using SolidWorks, so It was done with TinkerCAD, I did a few revisions but all ended having one problem or another.  
After gathering some experience with SolidWorks I decided to tackle Bender again, I have the individual parts in SolidWorks as well as the assembly, this was lacking in my past model, so it was a bit harder to understand how it all looked.  
For anyone interested in checking the SolidWorks files and modify them to fit perfectly feel free, the STL files are also there to send to a slicer directly.  
I still don't have a printer so I don't know how well it will print, but I hope someone goes ahead and prints this and gives feedback regarding the hits and misses.  
EDIT: Uploaded vertical STL files.
EDIT June 16 2017: Uploaded 3.4 and 3.5mm diameter pegs, because the 3.6mm one didn't fit.
EDIT: June 19 2017: Uploaded hand and foot with 4mm diameter ball joints as the original 3.6 were too loose.

title: Customizable Wide/Narrow Spool Adapter for Printrbot Simple XL

description.text:
There are many custom spool roller designs. Here's mine.  
Press fits into the default spool roller frame on top of Printrbot Simple XL. Adds a wider track (for ~90mm spools) and a narrower track (for ~58mm spools).

Printed mine with 0.3 mm layer height, 3 perimeters, 3 top/bottom layers, 0.1 honeycomb infill. Print two, obviously.  
I used "608" skateboard bearings. They're cheap - you can find packages of 8 or 10 for less than $5. I used some stray M3 bolts and small washers to hold them in place. I had to drill out the holes a bit.

Using the following options:

Development stage: Work in progress
It measures 30 cm or 12 inch diameter. The discs will be 6 cm apart.
This is a filament spool that can be be mounted on the side of the Darwin. The image is an artistic illustration. When I've refined it an laser cut it, I will also post the final SVG that I have used for it.
If you have suggestions, please let me know.
It was made in Inkscape.

For the "Full version" you'll need:
15 M8 nuts (approximately)
2 skate bearings (I got mine from RRRF)
3 diagonal tie brackets
3 pieces of M8 threaded rod, each about 10 cm long.
1 some super glue (optional) It was made for 6 mm acrylic, since It is strong and simply since I have a lot if it. The design is very easily adjusted for other sizes, almost all of the holes are cloned, you change the size of all of them if you change one. The arcs that are missing (lasered out) are used to connect two of the lasered 'discs'. They will be evenly spaced. They should fit tightly (6mm). I've added three holes for your finger (to turn it) if you want to roll filament onto it. There is one elliptical hole, you can put the end of the filament through here and perhaps put a screw terminal on it so it stays in place. You need to use an extra diagonal tie bracket to attach the center axis. Two more of you make the arms that keep the spindle tightly.

description.text:
Some people get away without using springs on wade's geared extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1794), but I felt that this was too sensitive to being over/under tightened. I wasn't able to find appropriately sized springs at the local hardware store either. I did cut some longer springs down to size, but I also made these. At least in the short term, they seem to work about as well as actual springs. The biggest difference is that they don't have as much travel. In my opinion, that actually helps with loading new filament since you aren't fighting as hard to push the bearing back. I just made them today, so I do not know how well they will hold up over time though. EDIT:
I have attempted a dozen or so prints using these springs. Most had to be aborted due to filament jams or bad settings, but I do not think this was related to the springs. They did develop flat spots on the side that presses against the idler block, but turning the screws one full revolution seemed to fix the resulting loss of pressure. I have yet to see if they will take the heat of a 3+ hour print though.

I printed my springs with ABS. I don't know how well PLA springs would work. Printing one file will give you two springs. The idea is basically the same as leaf springs on a truck. Place the curved side against the idler block and clamp it down with screws through the slotted holes. EDIT:
I am including the original *.ipt file for anyone that wants to edit the part. Note that I rotate my parts to a printable angle after saving them as STL's. If you edit the original drawing, you will have to rotate the part to make it printable. If you only want to print the part, all you need is the *.stl file. You do not have to download both files.

comments.text: any updates on this? is it reliable? Thanks

comments.text: For the time being, I would have to say this is not reliable. They work in a pinch and I see ways of making it better, but the initial results were not impressive by any means. The springs you see here failed after three weeks or so.

description.text: Full enclosure for the main PCB of a Logitech C920 webcam, sans optics, for use in prime focus astrophotography.

Requires some soldering skill. Some parts may require trimming to fit.
  • Disassemble a Logitech C920 webcam and extract the main PCB with the attached USB cable.
  • Remove the two screws holding the auto-focus assembly to the PCB. Save these screws for later.
  • Carefully desolder the auto-focus motor and remove the assembly without damaging the PCB. Important: DO NOT TOUCH THE SENSOR!
  • Print ccd_cover.stl and adapter.stl using a 0.2?m layer height.
  • Insert the square end of the CCD cover into the square hole in the telescope adapter on the side away from the tube (not inside the tube). Attach with super glue and allow to dry.
  • Print back.stl using a 0.3?m layer height and check that the adapter fits. Sand and trim as necessary.
  • Attach the CCD cover to the PCB in place of the original auto-focus assembly using the two screws saved earlier. Again, be sure to avoid contact with the sensor, which should be centered in the square window inside the tube.
  • Insert the PCB and attached front cover into the back of the enclosure. The USB cable should fit through the provided slot with the rubber strain relief on the inside, to ensure tension on the cable is transmitted to the case and not the PCB.
  • Secure the front of the case to the back with small screws in each of the four corners, or (as I did) by wrapping both ends of the case in clear tape.
  • (Optional) Print cap.stl to cover the end of the tube and protect the sensor when not in use. You may find it a bit large; I wrapped the outer edge in black electrical tape for a more secure fit.

yeah "Dohickey" does print without support with maybe a few stray loops on the belly.
(i usually post pics of the model on the build plate to illustrate the 'hot off the presses' model.)
Mostly I try to avoid support, but of late I have just embraced the waste and annoying cleanup
in order to get a pose/model.
I have been doing a bunch of stuff that haven't been "published" with support.
Support is a pain but I have gotten decent results with minimal work on the clean-up (see my "fluffy" for a good example).
especially when using vapor polishing, the scars of support removal are further diminished.

comments.text: I really need to get into the vapor business soon. I've been meaning to try that for a while. I also haven't printed with support yet, but maybe on my next machine. Although, are you doing support on your Rep 1?
comments.author: cerberus333

comments.text:
yep rep one single extruder
I post pics with the support so you can see how it looks (and which machine I printed on)
support can be a pain to remove, but I have the hang of it and
at worst I have to acetone glue a break.(gotta love abs for how well it glues with acetone)
to vapor polish I use this method:
get a asparagus cooking pot (tall narrow pot with a basket to hold the asparagus)
I put a disc of aluminum foil (thick stuff from a take-out tin) on the bottom of the basket.
put model on the disc, in the basket.
2-3 tablespoons of acetone in the pot. heat on a electric hotplate.
put basket in pot with lid on tight 30 - 40 seconds
remove basket, air dry for 1-2 minutes.
a glass lid is a big plus, you can watch the model "wet" from bottom to top,
remove when top is wet.(usually 30-40 seconds)

description.text: This thing is a fully customizable kit to print plates and bricks for custom brick-images. The images consist of small bricks of different sizes that are placed on a grid. With this kit you are able to print all necessary parts by yourself. If you print the bricks in different Color you can create nice-looking multi-color images. The result is great for kids as it is fun to assemble pictures with it. You can even create image templates from your own Images by using websites like http://www.pictobrick.de/en/pictobrick.shtml. The idea behind this thing belongs to a company in germany called "Ministeck" (www.ministeck.de). See what you can do with this here: http://de.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Datei:Ministeck-still_life.JPG&filetimestamp=20081113201711 This Thing is still a Work in Progress as my Printer currently is down - so I can't check if everything prints like it should. But the parts are small - so you don't have much to loose trying it. ;) EDIT 17:42: There has been a little bug in the scad-file which lead to wrong stick-hole-correspondance. It should be corrected now.

To make use of this kit simply take the pre-assembled stl-files. If you encounter problems printing them, need different sizes or amount or want to have special variations try the customizer. Printing the parts may be challenging as they are quite small. It may be easier printing more bricks at once as they then have more time to cool down. Using a fan, lowering the speed or using the "cool"-feature in your slicer might help, too. By using the customizer you have different options: - Single Piece Size: defines the "top size" of a single one-brick (width and height, x and y). The smaller the more filigree (and more challenging). Bigger means easier to print but also less detail on the final Images. - Block Thickness: defines the height of the "upper part" of the bricks. Make it thinner (smaller) to flatten the surface of the resulting Images. - Stick Length: defines the length of the sticks that attach the bricks to the grid. Also defines the height of the grid when choosing the thing type "base plate". - Thing type: defines which part you want to generate. You can choose between:
-> "complete block set": some bricks of all types
-> "base plate": the grid to attach the bricks to
-> "one-block": a single brick
-> "two-block": a two-sized brick
-> "three-block": a three-sized brick
-> "four-block": a quad-sized brick
-> "corner-block": a three-sized brick that "goes around the Corner"
-> "test set": a small set including all brick-types and a small base plate - use it to check whether the Settings work for your Printer or not. - Base Plate X Count: defines how many holes the base plate should have in the x-direction. Only relevant if the thing type is set to "base plate". - Base Plate Y Count: defines how many holes the base plate should have in the y-direction. Only relevant if the thing type is set to "base plate". - How Many: allows to print multiple instances of all brick types and the "complete set" - not relevant for "base plate" and "test set" If you have any question feel free to ask. Happy printing!

description.text:
I needed a wide-jet right-angle pipe for my aquarium, so I made it in OpenSCAD.
I made it in PLA, but actually I'm not sure it's perfectly safe for fishes and plants...

Change parameters to fit length, diameter and dimension of the wide-jet output (it affects flow speed, and turbolence).
I printed it with my ReprapPro Huxley, using 0.25mm layer height and 100% infill.

description.text:
I created two variants of support...both based on enif design.
1st one is using plastic clamps in order to fix the support to the motorbike, 2nd one is using a velcro strap i took from my old garmin.
Found this puzzle on Wikipedia and kinda wanted to print it.
A clamp to hold the MakerBot Z platform in place while moving/shipping.  It's intentionally undersized to be snug.
Print four and clip on to the Z rods just above the wooden Z platform nut caps.  To be super sure, print another four and put them below the z rod nuts as well.  The Z platform will not move.

author: matriedel

title: Radial Spool Holder for Al Frame Prusa i3

description.text: I wanted a simple top mounted spool holder. seeing as the axle ones tend to fail after a while and I wanted something that didn't protrude out of the front much, and so this was conceived. Made it quite strong so it can probably handle even the bigger variety of spool.

Print the left and right side holder, they are exactly the same but for a built in washer to space the bearings.
Use M8 threaded rod with nuts washers and bearings (I used 608 bearings, the same as in the Greg Wade extruder). Space the sides appropriately apart and simply place the spool on top.
I only used threaded rod on one side and bolts on the other to keep it lighter and simpler.
Suggest making the threaded long enough to accommodate the widest spool you could ever use just in case, made mine 200mm.
The bush has an inner diameter of 22mm and works great to line up the spool. Suggest using concentric as it is already a round object and it makes it look that much neater

comments.text:
Made one, nice design ! Thanks !
May I suggest to design stronger bushes ? the ones here have 2 layers (0.3x2) on the thinnest part. I use cheap PLA and cheap PLA is quite brittle with such wall thickness
comments.author: Gilles31

comments.text: Thanks for the feed back. The reason I made them so was that I was pretty limited by the width of the bearing but wanted the groove as deep as possible. Didn't think of the cheaper PLA. Thanks for the tip
comments.author: Gilles31

comments.text: The bearing fits well, pretty tight. You could increase (translate) the external envelope of the bush in order to add a couple mm but I don't know which software you use and with STLs I'm not able to do it. Luckily I have some PET left, I may give it a try with PET which is stiff and not not so brittle
comments.author: Thirkell

comments.text: Wanted to keep it as small as possible. I shall adjust the drawing and upload a new one when I get a chance. Intentionally made the bearing a transition fit in the bush so everything stayed where it was meant to be.
comments.author: Gilles31

comments.text: What infill and shell number do you use?
comments.author: GrupoCPI

comments.text: I used PLA with 0.3 layer height and 20% rectilinear infill to save on time and printer wear. I use 3 shell layers on all my prints.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:105814 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=105814

Using the following options: OD = 56
$fn = 100
ID = 19
hole_size = 1.5
clearance = 5
spool_width = 30
wall_thickness = 3
4 balls together tip on one ball when rotated

On my replicator I print with exterior support, layer 0.2. The top ball has a support structure that must be removed and should allow to print this without support, but you will need a printer that is better calibrated than mine. As with my thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38459 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:37177, tipping is caused by friction, so use sand paper on the bottom three balls where they connect with the table to have the tetrahedron tip faster. Normally tipping goes to one of the three base balls you start with, and not to the top ball. So this does not show a full tipping behavior. I'll test a bit with different masses to see if different behavior can be achieved. Paint the balls in different colors to see to which ball it tips. The balls have a shell of 0.8 as my nozzle is 0.4, use the openscad with the scad file to change the shell thickness if you have different nozzle. While trying to find a good name for this thing, I found you can buy it as Tetra Tops, see google image search for some configurations. I actually saw this myself for the first time in a science activity for young children. Just glue with superglue 4 marbles in this configuration, and you will have the tipping effect. A really nice toy and easy to make. But if you have a printer, you can as well print it big!
